comment.author: 23103743@N05
comment._content: A photo dated 1915 of what might well be the actor, taken by Arnold Genthe (who took portrait photos of many actors), is at www.loc.gov/pictures/item/agc1996004197/PP/ That photo looks older, but there are similarities, and makeup can be deceiving.

comment.author: 76016463@N00
comment._content: There is a Robert Lee Keeling (1865 or 1870 to ?), miniaturist and brother to Rose Keeling Hutchins, wife of the Washington Post founder Stilson Hutchins. He and she are mentioned regularly in the society pages of the New York Times in this era. I haven't seen anything mentioning that he was also a movie actor, so they could well be different people. The actor's movie career doesn't seem to have started until 1918, when the miniaturist was 48, while Mrs. Hutchins' 1926 obituary describes her brother as "the miniaturist of New York City." However, the miniaturist R.L. Keeling was in some professional productions in the 1890's. A profile of the miniaturist at select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F60C13F6385D1373... As an artist and wealthy socialite, one can imagine him as the subject of offbeat portraits such as this one and the one by Genthe. However, this portrait in not of a 45 year old man, so if it is the same subject as Genthe's, it was taken long before 1915.

comment.author: 23103743@N05
comment._content: @artolog, More fodder for detective work. I found a picture (and profile as a member of society in Washington DC) of the miniaturist at books.google.com/books?id=gm4eAQAAMAAJ&pg=PA250&l... in an 1898 issue of The International. It could be the same man at the same sort of age. And NYT September 19, 1897 query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=FA0D14FC3B5D11738... reports the death of a wife (a widow 20 years his senior) with whom he lived briefly before separating. It mentions that he was on the stage before taking up painting as a career.

comment.author: 23103743@N05
comment._content: The history of tweed for gentlemen's jackets doesn't really help with the dating. According to www.harristweed.org/fabric_hist.htm marketing of the fabric outside the Scottish islands began around 1850 and an improved loom was introduced in 1903. 1903-1906 saw a boom and led to the establishment of the Harris Tweed trademark around 1910. So this could possibly be a photo of a fashion leader around 1900. By 1915, I think tweed would have been common for outdoor activities, at least in UK society. NYT of May 12, 1902 query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=FA0813FF385412738... reports that the miniaturist was to sail for London to paint a miniature of King Edward. So that Robert Lee Keeling could have had a jacket tailored for him while there.

comment.author: 35234565@N04
comment._content: Please keep up the great detective work, all of you. I'm going to hold off making any changes yet.
